content: The "Individual Investment Account Act of 1999" establishes Individual Investment Accounts under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Individual Investment Account Act of 1999 allows individuals to deduct cash payments made to an individual investment account established for their benefit. An individual investment account is a trust created in the U.S. for the exclusive benefit of an individual, with specific requirements for contributions and trustees. The Individual Investment Account Act of 1999 allows individuals to deduct cash payments made to an individual investment account established for their benefit. The trust assets must not be invested in collectibles and should not be commingled with other property, except in a common trust fund. Contributions are deemed made on the last day of the taxable year if made on account of that year and before the deadline for filing the tax return. Tax treatment of distributions is also specified. The Individual Investment Account Act of 1999 allows deductions for cash payments made to an individual investment account. Distributions from the account are taxable unless used for a qualified 1st-time homebuyer distribution within 60 days. Custodial accounts are treated as trusts if held by a bank or another entity meeting certain criteria. The trustee of an individual investment account must report to the Secretary and the account holder on contributions, distributions, and other matters as required by regulations. A deduction for individual investment account contributions is allowed in arriving at adjusted gross income. Individual Investment Accounts Exempt From Estate Tax: Section 222 allows deductions for individual investment accounts. Part III of chapter 11 of the Code is amended to exempt these accounts from estate tax. Individual investment accounts are excluded from the gross estate value and not subject to Section 1014. A new section allows the exclusion of gain from the sale of a principal residence if reinvested in an individual investment account. The tax code allows for the exclusion of gain from the sale of a principal residence if the property has been owned and used as the taxpayer's main home for at least 3 years within a 5-year period. The amount of gain excluded cannot exceed the cash amount paid into an individual investment account within a year of the sale. Ownership and use rules similar to section 121(d) apply for determining eligibility. Additionally, there are provisions for taxing prohibited transactions under Section 4975 of the tax code.
